text: K-149 is a north-south state highway in the U.S. state of Kansas. K-149's southern terminus is at U.S. Route 56 (US-56) east of Delavan and the northern terminus is at K-4 south of White City. Before state highways were numbered in Kansas there were Auto trails, the southern terminus follows the former National Old Trails Road, Old Santa Fe Trail and South West Trail. K-149 was first designated a state highway on February 13, 1957. ==Route description== K-149 begins at an intersection with US-56, about west of Council Grove, and begins traveling northward through rural grasslands. After roughly the highway passes through a small forested area at the crossing of an unnamed creek then transitions back to grasslands and intersects T Avenue. The highway continues north for then curves to the east at Q Avenue. K-149 continues for about the curves back to the north. From here it continues north for roughly and crosses the West Fork Neosho River, a tributary of the Neosho River. It continues north for about then passes by an abandoned schoolhouse. From here it continues north for another roughly through flat rural farmlands before reaching its northern terminus at K-4, about south of White City. The Kansas Department of Transportation (KDOT) tracks the traffic levels on its highways, and in 2017, they determined that on average the traffic was 175 vehicles per day on K-149. K-149 is not included in the National Highway System. The National Highway System is a system of highways important to the nation's defense, economy, and mobility. The entire route is paved with partial design bituminous pavement. ==History== Before state highways were numbered in Kansas there were Auto trails, which were an informal network of marked routes that existed in the United States and Canada in the early part of the 20th century. The southern terminus follows the former National Old Trails Road, Old Santa Fe Trail and South West Trail. K-149 was first designated a state highway by the Kansas State Highway Commission, now known as KDOT, on February 13, 1957. K-149's alignment has not changed since it was created. ==Major intersections== ==References== ==External links== *Kansas Department of Transportation State Map *KDOT: Historic State Maps 149 Category:Transportation in Morris County, Kansas
title: K-149 (Kansas highway)
